marklogic.body:
“Research affirms that there is in fact a kind of hole in the addict’s soul”
No, clearly research has never affirmed anything about a soul, nor about God, nor Satan, nor Unicorns. This absurdity seems to set the tone for the remainder of this piece.
“ . . . attendance at ritualized 12-step meetings offers communion with like-minded folk and a safe haven from Anxiety and loneliness.”
That sounds like a wonderful thing that would appeal to almost anyone. Who wouldn’t want to stop being anxious and lonely? And for free, without having to pay for treatment of any kind! But how to explain, then, that almost everyone who tries the meetings stops coming?
“ . . . relieving 12-steppers’ of their narcissism and other personality flaws.”
Wow, who knew that the 12 steps could be effective in treating personality disorders, the most refractory of mental health disorders? The referrals are going to start streaming in. Seriously, though, could you cite just one study to support that claim? Otherwise, I fear that some readers may begin to suspect that you are fabricating.
“The 12-step approach to spirituality long ago proved its benefits . . .”
No, as a matter of fact, there is no scientific evidence to establish that the 12-Step approach to anything has benefits for addictive or other problem behaviors.
“What’s new is that science is backing spirituality as a recovery tool—and not just the 12-step version . . .”
Could you cite just one randomized, controlled study that supports the claim that “the 12-Step version” is effective compared to control groups as a recovery tool in treating addiction or any other problem?
“Florida State University research by Nathanial Lambert and Frank Fincham recently found that people in recovery who pray more drink less—even if they’re not praying in order to stop drinking . . . “
Depending on how the study was designed, that could mean absolutely nothing, or just about anything: for example that individuals highly motivated to stop drinking are also motivated to engage in practices (like prayer) suggested to them to help with sobriety; that individuals who attend church (and pray) are more likely to be affluent, have resources and stability that reduce stress; that individuals who are more involved in organized religion are more likely to dishonestly report levels of alcohol use, etc., etc.
“Surrendering to a Higher Power (HP) is, in the 12-step model, essential to recovery. And there is growing scientific support for this belief: Ken Pargament at Ohio’s Bowling Green State University showed that chanting mantras like “God is great” (or “Mother Earth is great” for the humanists) lets people keep their hands in ice water for twice as long as mantras like “Life is good” or “I am happy.”
It proves the opposite – that by the self-determined behavioral choice of focusing on chanting, an individual can consciously distract from discomfort, affirming his or her powerfulness, not powerlessness. A more interesting test of the 12-Step model would have been to have subjects chant, “I am powerless” or “Only God can help me”.
“But psychologists and psychiatrists are more relaxed about what qualifies as spiritual, whether in the minds of addicts or others. They say it can range from conventionally religious activities to art appreciation, long outdoor walks, cooking, rewarding time with family and friends or even simple peace and quiet. The ability to soothe oneself comes in almost as many names as forms: call it a holding environment, emotional R&R, mental hygiene, self-care.”
That’s right, none of which has anything to do with the odd and countertherapeutic precepts of the 12 Steps.
“Lambert and Fincham, in Florida, were surprised to learn that their praying subjects’ private murmurings, while directed at loved ones, made them drink less . . .”
No reason for surprise. As Marlatt’s research supports, meditative activities, which are physiologically calming, enhance positive thoughts and connections to a social world, and improve mood, would be expected to have recovery value.
Bottom line – there has long been support for the ideas that positive connections to others in thought or deeds and relaxation techniques such as meditation have positive effects in recovery. If those positive factors had any relationship to the odd religious beliefs and practices embodied in the 12 Steps, then we would expect different results than 90 to 95% failure rates.
